TitleMain.Title: Recent immigrants : unexpected implications for crime and incarceration

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Cambridge, Massachusetts, National Bureau of Economic Research [NBER], 1997.
PublicationInfo.Place: Cambridge, Massachusetts, National Bureau of Economic Research [NBER],

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: "Among 18-40 year old men in the United States, immigrants are less likely to be institutionalized than the native-born, and much less likely to be institutionalized than native-born men with similar demographic characteristics. Furthermore, earlier immigrants are more likely to be institutionalized than more recent immigrants....These results are the opposite of what one would predict from the literature on immigrant earnings, where earlier immigrants are typically found to have better permanent labor market characteristics." (Excerpt)

TitleMain.Title: Prisons and AIDS.

Author.CollectiveName: Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Both drug use and sexual contact between men are common in prisons around the world. Rates of HIV infection are also high in many prisons. General factors which can facilitate HIV transmission in prisons include overcrowding; a general climate of violence, tension, and fear; lack of information about HIV; and lack of adequate health facilities. Specific factors include the injection of drugs with shared, unsterilized needles and syringes; unprotected penetrative sex between men; and tattooing with shared, unsterilized equipment. Since prisons and prisoners are not completely cut off from the rest of the world, all possible steps should be taken to prevent HIV transmission in prisons for the benefit of both prisoners and the rest of society. Prisoners, prison staff, and visitors move in and out of prisons on a daily basis; many prisoners are incarcerated for only short periods; and others are repeat offenders who enter and exit the non-prison society on a regular basis. Providing discreet and easy access to condoms, and making sterile injection equipment available to prisoners are among the approaches recommended to help reduce the spread of HIV. One important, positive measure would be to transfer the delivery of health care in prisons to the control of public health authorities. Isolating prisoners because they are HIV-seropositive tends to not help reduce HIV transmission.

TitleMain.Title: Annual report to Congress 1997.

Author.CollectiveName: United States. Physician Payment Review Commission.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Washington, DC : Physician Payment Review Commission, 1997.

Abstract.AbstractText: SUMMARY : Over the past decade, the American health system has changed dramatically. In the mid-1980s, most Americans with health insurance, whether public or private, had indemnity coverage, as they had 20 years earlier when Medicaid was enacted. Congressional action affecting the Medicare program, including major reforms in hospital and physician payment, assumed that fee-for-service medicine would remain the principal form of health care financing and delivery. Today's market is markedly different. The number of people with traditional indemnity insurance has been shrinking. Managed-care plans are evolving into integrated systems with closer links to their provider networks, while physicians and hospitals are joining together in new types of organizations. Responding to climbing premiums, leading corporate purchasers of health care are changing how they pay for health services, with potential consequences for costs and quality. These trends present Medicare, Medicaid, and the broader health system with new challenges. Over the past year, the Physician Payment Review Commission has analyzed critical issues concerning the future of these programs - issues that affect Medicare managed care and fee for service, issues relevant to Medicaid managed care, and issues affecting other aspects of the health system.

TitleMain.Title: The other side of devolution : shifting relationships between state and local governments. Evidence from social services, public assistance, and workforce development programs

TitleOther.TitleAlternate: Assessing the New Federalism: occasional paper ; no. 2

Abstract.AbstractText: Assessing the New Federalism is a multi-year Urban Institute project designed to analyze the devolution of responsibility for social programs from the federal government to the states, focusing primarily on health care, income, security, job training, and social services. Researchers monitor program changes and fiscal developments, and changes in family well-being. The project aims to provide timely, nonpartisan information to inform public debate and to help state and local decisionmakers carry out their new responsibilities more effectively. Key components of the project include a household survey, studies of policies in thirteen states, and a database with information on all states and the District of Columbia, available at the Urban Institute's Web site. This paper is one in a series of occasional papers analyzing information from these and other sources.

TitleMain.Title: Rural health network evolution in the antitrust environment
TitleMain.OtherInformation: / N. P. Motenko, I. Moscovice, A. Wellever.

TitleOther.TitleAlternate: Working Paper / Rural Health Research Center ; no. 18

Author.CollectiveName: University of Minnesota. Rural Health Research Center.

Abstract.AbstractText: INTRODUCTION: The 1996 Policy Statements now give explicit encouragement to several types of rural health network formation and activity, thus paving the way for a "new" antitrust environment that is more sensitive to the special problems of competition and market power in rural areas. This paper is designed to help equip rural health leaders with a realistic, up-to-date overview of antitrust issues relevant to rural health care and specifically to rural health networks. "Rural Health Network Evolution in the New Antitrust Environment" has three major content areas: 1) the basics of antitrust and health care (Appendix), 2) the antitrust issues relevant to rural health care networks (Chapters 1 and 2), and 3) the strategies that can allow network development without running afoul of antitrust laws (Chapters 3 and 4). CHAPTER 1: ANTITRUST FOR HEALTH CARE PROVIDER NETWORKS: ISSUES OF PRACTICAL CONCERN: The antitrust issues of practical concern for health care networks generally, whether urban or rural, fall into two categories: (a) pricing and "integration" and (b) network membership and size. PRICE-FIXING among competitive health care providers is unlawful on its face (the legal term is "per se"). Integrated joint ventures are entitled to determine their pricing. In the absence of financial risk sharing, network pricing could be achieved through the use of a "messenger model." The 1996 Policy Statements on physician networks expanded the criteria for financial RISK-SHARING. They also articulate a newly recognized avenue (beyond financial risk-sharing) which can justify joint pricing by network providers: clinical integration. The Statements suggest that substantial clinical integration can be key to justifying such joint pricing. SIZE AND EXCLUSIVITY issues comprise the second major area of antitrust concern for provider networks. Selective contracting encourages the network to choose providers based on competitive factors such as quality of care, productivity, willingness to share risk, experience, and fit with the network's culture. It also rewards networks that select providers who know how to (a) manage utilization, (b) practice effectively under capitation or other risk-sharing arrangements, and (c) achieve economies of scale and administrative efficiencies. In general, EXCLUSIVE DEALING is unreasonable only when a significant percentage of buyers or sellers is frozen out of a market as a result. The Statements identify five criteria used to determine whether a network is exclusive or not. A rural health network risks a challenge to "unreasonable exclusionary conduct" if it excludes a class of providers, including allied health care professionals, without sufficient procompetitive justification -- especially when the exclusion is motivated by attempting to remove the competitive threat posed by that group to physician groups. As long as a network's procompetitive benefits outweigh its anticompetitive harm, the agencies have frequently announced their intention not to challenge networks, especially non-exclusive ones, with market shares substantially above 30 percent. It is more risky for the network to be too big than for it to make selective, procompetitive decisions about "who's in and who's out." CHAPTER 2: ANTITRUST LAW AND ENFORCEMENT APPLIED TO RURAL HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS: The "relevant market" for antitrust purposes defines the parameters (in terms of services and geography) in which the network's power to control prices or exclude competition within the market will be assessed. The definition of the relevant market is thus critical to the analysis of the market power of a health care provider network. Judicial focus is shifting from static analysis of where patients currently go for health care, toward a dynamic analysis of where health care consumers practically might turn. This shift is of particular importance to rural health care providers, whose facilities are often located at significant distances from other providers. To the extent that rural hospitals formed a network to achieve clinical or administrative efficiencies, their horizontal agreement (for example, on pricing) arguably does not raise antitrust problems if there is no competition among the parties. If any recent case reinforced fears - ultimately misplaced - about the application of the antitrust laws to rural providers, it was Marshfield Clinic. Although holding that Marshfield Clinic did not have monopoly power in the regions of North Central Wisconsin at issue, the court did suggest that the Clinic was a monopolist with respect to those areas so small that it employs all of the "handful" of physicians in that particular region. The court characterized the Clinic as holding a natural monopoly in those areas. (ABSTRACT TRUNCATED)

TitleMain.Title: The germ genie
TitleMain.OtherInformation: [videorecording] / a presentation of Films for the Humanities & Sciences ; Wildcat Films production for BBC Television.

TitleOther.TitleAlternate: Germ genie, the threat of biological warfare

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Princeton, N.J. : Films for the Humanities & Sciences, c1997.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Biological weapons offer a cheap alternative to nuclear weapons for smaller states and terrorist groups. This program traces the history of biological warfare from the Middle Ages, then looks at the latest biological weapons research under way in laboratories in the U.S. and U.K. While military experts offer defensive strategies, skeptical scientists discuss whether defense against germ warfare is possible. A reconstruction of anthrax fermentation demonstrates the ease with which the bacteria can be produced.

TitleMain.Title: Clinton/anti-cancer

PhysicalDescription.Extent: Master : 1 videocassette of 1 (VHS) (ca. 23 min.) : sd., col. ; 1/2 in.
Viewing copy : 1 videodisc of 1 (DVD) (ca. 23 min.) : sd., col. ; 4 3/4 in.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Presents unedited footage of President Clinton sitting at his desk in the Oval Office, surrounded by child cancer patients and survivors. He speaks to the children and then signs a proclamation declaring that Apr. 1996 will be Cancer Control Month. Short break in footage as the group moves to the East Room for a series of remarks about changes in the approval process for cancer drugs. Donna Shalala, secretary of the Dept. of Health and Human Services, welcomes the audience, Stacey Oller speaks and introduces Clinton, and Clinton elaborates on the drug approval reforms. Ends with scenes of Clinton and Vice President Gore greeting members of the audience.

NLMCatalogRecord.GeneralNote: Country of Producing Entity: United States.
Recorded Mar. 29, 1996 at a White House ceremony and press conference. Date on cassette label: Apr. 11, 1996.
Videodisc (DVD) 1 videodisc (23 min.) : sd., col., 4 3/4 in.

TitleMain.Title: Cancer drug treatment approval process

PhysicalDescription.Extent: Master : 1 videocassette of 1 (VHS) (ca. 22 min.) : sd., col. ; 1/2 in.
Viewing copy : 1 videodisc of 1 (DVD) (ca. 22 min.) : sd., col. ; 1/2 in.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Vice President Gore speaking to the press about reforms to the cancer drug approval process. Reforms stem from the reinventing government initiative and national performance review at the Food and Drug Administration (FDA). David Kessler, FDA commissioner, then elaborates on the reforms. These include faster approval by accepting surrogate markers of effectiveness, expedited availability of drugs approved overseas, the inclusion of cancer patients in FDA advisory committee meetings that address cancer drugs, and a reduction in paperwork for non-commercial clinical investigators. Kessler stresses that these reforms will not compromise high standards. Ends with question and answer session.

TitleMain.Title: Network coverage of cancer initiative, White House announcement

PhysicalDescription.Extent: Master : 1 videocassette of 1 (VHS) (ca. 7 min.) : sd., col. ; 1/2 in.
Viewing copy : 1 videodisc of 1 (DVD) (ca. 7 min.) : sd., col. ; 4 3/4 in.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Reports on the announcement of a cancer drug approval initiative at a White House press conference. First three segments repeat footage from HF2955 and HF5791, including remarks by Food and Drug Administration commissioner David Kessler. Final segment provides additional discussion of the initiative, which is intended to speed the approval process through changes in required study data, access to drugs manufactured and approved overseas, and expanded access to experimental drugs.

TitleMain.Title: Cancer initative [sic] : Kessler on camera.

PhysicalDescription.Extent: Master : 1 videocassette of 1 (VHS) (ca. 2 min.) : sd., col. ; 1/2 in.
Viewing copy : 1 videodisc of 1 (DVD) (ca. 2 min.) : sd., col. ; 4 3/4 in.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Announces a cancer drug approval initiative. Reforms include allowing the "off label" use of drugs already approved for other conditions and expanded access to experimental drugs. Bob Arnot questions David Kessler, commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), about the risks involved with the new process. Kessler admits risks are inherent but states that the risk of doing nothing in the face of life-threatening disease is greater. Kessler also notes that there may be mistakes in allowing some drugs to be used. Sidney Wolfe, of Public Citizen, discusses the prospect of patient harm should the FDA not admit its mistakes quickly and fully.

TitleMain.Title: Cancer drugs : FDA. FDA : faster approval.

PhysicalDescription.Extent: Master : 1 videocassette of 1 (VHS) (ca. 3 min.) : sd., col. ; 1/2 in.
Viewing copy : 1 videodisc of 1 (DVD) (ca. 3 min.) : sd., col. ; 4 3/4 in.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: First segment (ca. 2 min.) announces a cancer drug approval initiative. Shows President Clinton speaking about delays in current approval process. Mentions two key rule changes: studies must only show that drugs provide a net benefit, such as tumor shrinkage, rather than proving that the drugs save lives; easier access to drugs already approved in other countries. Ends with a call for additional reforms at the Food and Drug Administration. Ca. 29 min., 30 sec. break before second segment (ca. 30 sec) begins. Reports on President Clinton's remarks and estimates significant reduction in approval time.

TitleMain.Title: Cancer initiative

PhysicalDescription.Extent: Master : 1 videocassette of 1 (VHS) (ca. 5 min.) : sd., col. ; 1/2 in.
Viewing copy : 1 videodisc of 1 (DVD) (ca. 5 min.) : sd., col. ; 4 3/4 in.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: First segment begins mid-sentence. Announces a cancer drug approval initiative. Goal is to reduce approval time from the current average of 12 months by allowing less stringent measures of a drug's effectiveness. Addresses whether the emphasis on cancer drugs will impede access to other medications. Very little break before second segment begins. Provides additional details about the initiative, such as steps to provide quicker access to drugs manufactured overseas. Dr. Harmon Eyre, American Cancer Society, speaks about the need to make drugs available as quickly as possible. Sen. Bill Frist talks about the value of outsourcing some functions of the Food and Drug Administration.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Presents remarks by an unidentified woman, presumably Stacey Oller, about her childhood experience of cancer. Discusses the availability of medicines to treat her condition and praises a forthcoming government initiative as a way to get treatment to people in need. TitleMain.Title: Dr. Burzynski

PhysicalDescription.Extent: Master : 1 videocassette of 1 (VHS) (ca. 18 min.) : sd., col. ; 1/2 in.
Viewing copy : 1 videodisc of 1 (DVD) (ca. 18 min.) : sd., col. ; 4 3/4 in.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Reports on Dr. Stanislaw Burzynski and his patients in their struggle with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA). Burzynski dispenses an unapproved drug, antineoplaston, to cancer patients. Several patients feel the drug has saved their lives. The FDA is trying to stop Burzynski. Focuses on the efforts of a group of patients to raise funds for Burzynski's legal expenses and to speak on his behalf both in Congressional hearings and at the FDA. One commercial interruption.

TitleMain.Title: Medical men at Norfolk Island : the first settlement, 1788-1814

Author.OtherInformation: Department of Child Health, Universitiy of Nottingham, Queen's Medical Centre, England.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Brisbane : The Australia Society of the History of Medicine, 1996.
PublicationInfo.Publisher: The Australia Society of the History of Medicine,

Abstract.AbstractText: During its first settlement (1788-1814) Norfolk Is. was served by 16 medical men - 5 or possibly 6 of whom were or had been medical transportees. Most of these doctors were not formally qualified. They came involuntarily, either as colonial medical officers assigned to a tour of duty or as convicts.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Covacevich J; Pearn J; Case D, et al., eds. History, heritage and health. Proceedings of the Fourth Biennial Conference of the Australian Society of the History of Medicine; 1995 Jul 2-9; Norfolk Island

TitleMain.Title: A base propensity to mischief : the case of the medical officer and female chit-chat

Author.OtherInformation: Department of History, University of Queensland, Australia.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Brisbane : The Australia Society of the History of Medicine, 1996.
PublicationInfo.Publisher: The Australia Society of the History of Medicine,

Abstract.AbstractText: Why was the character of the doctor at Norfolk Is. the subject of a court of enquiry in November 1829? Was he, as alleged, an intemperate befuddled drunkard who shamefully neglected his patients or was A.J. Ross the subject of a systematic campaign of vilification? Could the scandal-mongers really be the genteel wife of the military commandant or the depressed spouse of the discontented Superintendent of Agriculture and, when placed in context with essential administrative decisions, was excessive consequence being accorded to frivolous female chit-chat? This small local investigation has its value in amplifying the social scene soon after the arrival of Commandant Morisset. Usually transfers of military officers and members of civil establishments are relegated to a single line in official records while the smouldering emotional background finally fades with fickle memory being quickly superseded by the next day's events. This reconstruction draws attention to the physical state of the settlement and to people who briefly came into contact with each other for one short period when they lived and worked together.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Covacevich J; Pearn J; Case D, et al., eds. History, heritage and health. Proceedings of the Fourth Biennial Conference of the Australian Society of the History of Medicine; 1995 Jul 2-9; Norfolk Island

TitleMain.Title: The doctor as governor : John Stephen Hampton

Author.OtherInformation: Department of Paediatrics, University of Western Australia.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Brisbane : The Australia Society of the History of Medicine, 1996.
PublicationInfo.Publisher: The Australia Society of the History of Medicine,

Abstract.AbstractText: Western Australia asked for convicts. From 1850, for 18 years, over 10,000 came. All were male, one third were Irish. Dr John Stephen Hampton, Edinburgh graduate, rose in the Royal Navy to Surgeon-Superintendent and became Comptroller General of Convicts in Van Dieman's Land in 1846. Energetic and strict, he was charged with profiting by convict labour, but became Governor of Western Australia, arriving in Feb., 1862. He expanded the programme of building, and of making roads, jetties and bridges, and opened the north-west to lease. The colony prospered. The convicts did not. He appointed his overpaid son George, Comptroller-General, to heavy criticism. In their brutal reign, lashings returned massively and escapes multiplied, to public alarm. George was replaced and harsh punishment (and escapes) faded. Then came the mutiny that never was: the Hougoumont, the last ship to transport convicts, included 62 Fenians from rebellious Ireland. Faster ships carrying this news produced near-hysteria among influential ultra-loyalists in Perth. There were stories of a Fenian warship, of planned mutiny on the boat, of plots by Irish sympathizers, and the realization that three fifths of the British Army's Pensioner Guards in the colony were Irish. Hampton handled the situation very well. When he left in Nov., 1868 the colony was expanding and prosperous. So was he. His personal rule intensified the clamour for representative government which came in 1870.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Covacevich J; Pearn J; Case D, et al., eds. History, heritage and health. Proceedings of the Fourth Biennial Conference of the Australian Society of the History of Medicine; 1995 Jul 2-9; Norfolk Island

TitleMain.Title: William Evans and the Newcastle Convict Hospital, 1811-1822

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Brisbane : The Australian Society of the History of Medicine, 1996.
PublicationInfo.Publisher: The Australian Society of the History of Medicine,

Abstract.AbstractText: The Convict Hospital at Newcastle opened in a converted convict hut acquired in 1810-11, continuing after 1816-17 in purpose-built premises roughly on the same site and in the Newcastle Gaol, south of Nobbys Is. From the start of the settlement in 1804, medical care of the convicts and military establishment was in the hands of assistant Colonial Surgeons. William Evans, the third to hold the position, served in Newcastle from 1811-22. The existing records (particularly of the Bigge Inquiry) reveal much about contemporary medical orthodoxy, the diseases Evans treated including dysentery, pulmonary complaints, fevers, ophthalmia, dropsy, scurvy, scrofula and venereal diseases. The evidence also sheds light on the youthful Newcastle, place of secondary banishment prior to the settlements at Port Macquarie and Moreton Bay.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Covacevich J; Pearn J; Case D, et al., eds. History, heritage and health. Proceedings of the Fourth Biennial Conference of the Australian Society of the History of Medicine; 1995 Jul 2-9; Norfolk Island

TitleMain.Title: Death in custody : Japanese prisoners of war in Brisbane, Australia, 1942-1945
TitleMain.OtherInformation: / D. J. Williams, A. J. Ansford.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Brisbane : The Australian Society of the History of Medicine, 1996.
PublicationInfo.Publisher: The Australian Society of the History of Medicine,

Abstract.AbstractText: During World War II, Japanese soldiers captured in Papua New Guinea and adjacent islands were transferred to Enoggera Barracks, Brisbane, as prisoners of war. Deaths among Japanese prisoners of war were subject to coronial enquiry. Post-mortem examinations were principally performed by Dr Edward Derrick, the State Pathologist, who described much tropical pathology in the subjects. Surprisingly, there was only one suicide, the majority of the prisoners dying of deficiency diseases and of malaria. These Japanese deaths in custody can be contrasted with deaths in custody occurring in more modern times. Suicide has become a prominent cause of death. Ischaemic heart disease is the principal natural cause of death in Australian prisoners in the 1990's.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Covacevich J; Pearn J; Case D, et al., eds. History, heritage and health. Proceedings of the Fourth Biennial Conference of the Australian Society of the History of Medicine; 1995 Jul 2-9; Norfolk Island

TitleMain.Title: Convict life during transportation

Author.OtherInformation: Department of Anatomical Sciences, The University of Queensland, Australia.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Brisbane : The Australian Society of the History of Medicine, 1996.
PublicationInfo.Publisher: The Australian Society of the History of Medicine,

Abstract.AbstractText: On 10 Dec., 1817, 90 male convicts were taken aboard the transport ship, Tottenham, from the hulk Justitia at Woolwich in the River Thames. Another 62 were embarked at Sheerness from the hulk, Retribution and 48 from the hulk, Bellerephon, making a full complement of 200 men. The majority were sentenced in English courts, but six came from Scotland, three from Welsh courts and two from a Vallenciennes Court Martial. Their sentences ranged from 7 years to life. They were aged from 14 to 61 years and many were ill when they embarked. Some 10 months later, on 20 Oct., 1818, having survived the journey, 190 disembarked at Sydney Cove. This paper appraises at the day-to-day routine of shipboard life, some few incidents that broke the monotony, the illnesses suffered by the convicts and guards and the treatments used by the Naval Surgeon-Superintendent, Robert armstrong. This paper also follows the fate of one of these convicts whose sentence, 'to be hanged by the neck' was commuted to 'transportation for life' and whose descendents still live in Australia.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Covacevich J; Pearn J; Case D, et al., eds. History, heritage and health. Proceedings of the Fourth Biennial Conference of the Australian Society of the History of Medicine; 1995 Jul 2-9; Norfolk Island

TitleMain.Title: Scorbuticus et contusio : medical practice at the Macquarie Harbour Penal Settlement, Tasmania, Australia

Author.OtherInformation: Department of Child Health, Royal Children's Hospital, Brisbane, Queensland, Australia.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Brisbane : The Australian Society of the History of Medicine, 1996.
PublicationInfo.Publisher: The Australian Society of the History of Medicine,

Abstract.AbstractText: Macquarie Harbour, on the west coast of Tasmania, was the site of the world's most infamous penal colony from 1822 until 1833. Sarah Is. and its tiny satellite, Grummett Is., housed between 100 and 370 recidivist convicts. Judicial discipline was extremely harsh, and conditions of work exhausting and physically dangerous. Flogging occurred, on average, every second day. Convicts rowed boats to tow Huon Pine log rafts, cut timber, built ships, burnt lime, made leather and farmed. Many worked up to their waists in freezing water. In spite of this the health of convicts at Macquarie Harbour was surprisingly good. Scurvy occurred intermittently. The settlement was a wild and dangerous place; and 46 died violently. Attempted escapes - more than 140 - were common but few were successful. Impenetrable forests, lack of food and exposure killed escapees'. Eight medical men were associated with the penal station at Macquarie Harbour. One was a convict in the gaol cells; another was captured and kept by his convict charges en route to Macquarie Harbour. The six practising surgeons were a disparate group.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Covacevich J; Pearn J; Case D, et al., eds. History, heritage and health. Proceedings of the Fourth Biennial Conference of the Australian Society of the History of Medicine; 1995 Jul 2-9; Norfolk Island

TitleMain.Title: Aspects of internment in Australia during the First World War

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Brisbane : The Australian Society of the History of Medicine, 1996.
PublicationInfo.Publisher: The Australian Society of the History of Medicine,

Abstract.AbstractText: Internment without trial of civilians in Australia during the First World War was effected by regulations of the War Precautions Act. Recourse to the remedy of habeas corpus was disallowed on the grounds of national security. The internment of Eugen Hirschfeld and Carl Zoeller of Brisbane, in Feb., 1916 as persons of 'hostile origin and associations' had the hall-marks of political expediency rather than military necessity. However, the lot of these men has to be seen in the broader contest of the disastrous Gallipoli campaign and the higher casualty rates suffered by Australians on the Western Front in 1916 e.g. at Pozières and Fromelles. Zoeller's internment profoundly affected his life and that of his Australian-born wife. He had migrated to Australia from Germany in 1885 at the age of 17. He was denaturalised and deported in 1919 as 'undesirable to be released in the Commonwealth'. Correspondence from Zoeller to friends who were members of the medical and nursing professions at Marburg, Queensland provides insight into the psychological effects of idleness on this former medical and veterinary agent and surgical instrument manufacturer. The official title of the Australian internment camps as 'German Concentration Camps' now has an ironic twist given the advent of the Third Reich in the 1930s.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Covacevich J; Pearn J; Case D, et al., eds. History, heritage and health. Proceedings of the Fourth Biennial Conference of the Australian Society of the History of Medicine; 1995 Jul 2-9; Norfolk Island

TitleMain.Title: Birth of a nation : convict midwives

Author.OtherInformation: School of Science and Technology Studies, University of N.S.W., Sydney, Australia.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Brisbane : The Australian Society of the History of Medicine, 1996.
PublicationInfo.Publisher: The Australian Society of the History of Medicine,

Abstract.AbstractText: Midwifery in the early years of the 19th century in England had largely been appropriated by male doctors as a routine part of their practice. Female midwives fought hard in the preceding century to keep men out of their profession but the closing decades of the 1700s witnessed a preference for the man-midwife, with only the poor continuing to employ female midwives by the turn of the century. Midwives in France developed in status over this same period. Midwifery remained a primarily female profession with institutions such as the Hôtel-Dieu educating midwives in basic obstetrics and simple surgical techniques. In different ways the situation in both countries indicates that childbirth had become a process to be managed in a highly professional manner and accorded appropriate levels of respect. Against this background the new colony of New South Wales reverted to a system of primarily untrained, unqualified midwives. Birth in the first couple of decades was attended by physicians, but this soon changed for the majority of women. They were attended by women with the title midwife, but none of the associated expertise. These women were predominantly convicts sent on assignment with minimal training and no experience. Far from the growing status of midwifery/obstetrics experienced in their homeland, in the new colony this became an acceptable profession for convict women who would have otherwise had time on their hands.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Covacevich J; Pearn J; Case D, et al., eds. History, heritage and health. Proceedings of the Fourth Biennial Conference of the Australian Society of the History of Medicine; 1995 Jul 2-9; Norfolk Island

TitleMain.Title: Indulged with a marine excursion : medical memoranda on women convicts at sea, 1815-40

Author.OtherInformation: Department of History, University of Queensland, Australia.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Brisbane : The Australian Society of the History of Medicine, 1996.
PublicationInfo.Publisher: The Australian Society of the History of Medicine,

Abstract.AbstractText: Between 1788 and 1842, over 25,000 women were sentenced to transportation from the United Kingdom to New South Wales and Van Diemen's Land. After leaving the county and city gaols, their first great adventure was the long sea voyage - an overwhelming experience for both rural and urban-born. Were these vessels really coffin ships carrying diseased minds and bodies of wanton and abandoned criminals? 'If there ever was a hell afloat, it must have been in the shape of a female convict ship' was the opinion of Thratycles Clarke, the surgeon superintendent on the Kains voyage in 1830-1, while the experienced Robert Espie on the Lord Sidmouth in 1822 feelingly wrote, 'The duties of the Superintendence are far greater than those of surgeon'. They dealt with disease, dirt and discipline; regulated rations, riots and religion; ministered medication and mothering while mediating with mutineers as well as contending with climate, crews and children. This paper looks at the Journals of the medical men responsible for the female prisoners on their passages to Australia to assess the attitudes, accountability and obligations of these British Government officers to their charges.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Covacevich J; Pearn J; Case D, et al., eds. History, heritage and health. Proceedings of the Fourth Biennial Conference of the Australian Society of the History of Medicine; 1995 Jul 2-9; Norfolk Island

TitleMain.Title: Lunatics and convicts in the work of Bishop Willson

Author.OtherInformation: Medical History Unit, University of Melbourne, Australia.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Brisbane : The Australian Society of the History of Medicine, 1996.
PublicationInfo.Publisher: The Australian Society of the History of Medicine,

Abstract.AbstractText: Robert Willson, the first Catholic Bishop of Van Diemen's Land, was appointed in 1842. Previously he had been in Nottingham where, in addition to his highly successful pastoral duties, he was on the Board of the Lunatic Asylum. He also converted his own home to a Catholic private asylum. In Australia, he visited the Port Arthur and New Norfolk asylums in Van Diemen's Land, Yarra Bend in Victoria and Tarbon Ck and Parramatta in New South Wales. He heavily criticised them all to the governments, the press and medical journals. He visited the Catholic convicts in Van Diemen's Land and in Norfolk Is. on three occasions. He reported upon the dreadful conditions there to the local administration, protested to the British Government, and was largely responsible for the Lieutenant Governor, Sir William Denison's decision to advise the closure of Norfolk Is. As a result of Bishop Willson's activities, two cathedrals were built, the Australian asylums were reformed, a Royal Commission was empowered, a Select Committee of the House of Lords was convened, three Parliamentary Committees were authorised and three Acts of Parliament were promulgated. Finally, he was largely responsible for the removal of the Yarra Bend Asylum to Kew.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Covacevich J; Pearn J; Case D, et al., eds. History, heritage and health. Proceedings of the Fourth Biennial Conference of the Australian Society of the History of Medicine; 1995 Jul 2-9; Norfolk Island

TitleMain.Title: Fingersmiths, female factories and the famous

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Brisbane : The Australian Society of the History of Medicine, 1996.
PublicationInfo.Publisher: The Australian Society of the History of Medicine,

Abstract.AbstractText: About a sixth of all transported convicts were women. In the early years they were separated in 'Female Factories', the best known being at Parramatta. These were designed for work, punishment and obstetrical confinement. Hence they were the first maternity hospitals. Permanent midwives were appointed, known in convict slang as fingersmiths. Promiscuity and delinquency were rife. At the other extreme of the social ladder was William Redfern, a former convict who became obstetrician to the famous, including Governor Macquarie's wife. Sources used include early 18th century correspondence between the colony and England, statements by contemporary observers, and descriptions of contemporary obstetrics from the works of William smellie.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Covacevich J; Pearn J; Case D, et al., eds. History, heritage and health. Proceedings of the Fourth Biennial Conference of the Australian Society of the History of Medicine; 1995 Jul 2-9; Norfolk Island

TitleMain.Title: Prison medicine in South Africa : James Barry and Steve Biko
TitleMain.OtherInformation: / A. J. Brown, J. A. Barnes.

Author.OtherInformation: Adler Museum of the History of Medicine, Johannesburg, South Africa.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Brisbane : The Australian Society of the History of Medicine, 1996.
PublicationInfo.Publisher: The Australian Society of the History of Medicine,

Abstract.AbstractText: This paper sketches the history of prison medicine in South Africa and contrasts the cases of Dr James Barry (?1795-1865) and Mr Steve Biko (1946-1977). Barry was dismissed from the position of Colonial Medical Inspector for embarassing the government over their neglect of prisoners. Steve Biko, a political detainee, died of brain injury after an interrogation session. Although evidence indicated unethical behaviour by the two attending doctors they were cleared of misconduct by the South African Medical and Dental Council. The council refused to reopen the case until 1985 when they were ordered to do so by the Pretoria Supreme Court. This scandal rocked the South African medical world and resulted in a split in the ranks of the South African medical profession.

TitleMain.Title: Managed care : a risk manager's perspective.

Abstract.AbstractText: With healthcare reform initiatives sweeping across the United States, a definite trend has emerged toward managed healthcare delivery systems. The term "managed care8 encompasses many things, including health maintenance organizations (HMOs), managed home care, and managed Workers' Compensation care. As is true of other forms of healthcare delivery systems, managed care involves a number of different risk exposures: liability for negligence, failure to obtain consent, breach of confidentiality, and substandard credentialing practices. However, unlike other healthcare delivery systems, managed care has its own varieties of risk exposure that focus on contractual and financial considerations. This article provides an overview of the risk management issues involved in managed care. The intent is to provide traditional healthcare risk managers with a perspective on the types of liability exposures they may encounter as hospitals, long-term care facilities, and home care entities become involved in managed care. In addition, the article includes a glossary of terms frequently used in this delivery system and a Resource List.

TitleMain.Title: The legal framework for effective competition
TitleMain.OtherInformation: / R. A. Berenson, D. A. Hastings, W. G. Kopit.

Abstract.AbstractText: Largely because of its indifference to spiraling costs, the professional domination model is being replaced by a market model based on competition among managed care plans and integrated delivery systems. In general, the more fully integrated previously competing providers become--for instance, by assuming financial risk together--the less legal risk is present, because of a decreased possibility of improper conspiratorial or collective behavior. Nevertheless, provider joint ventures and integrated delivery systems face a complex interaction of practical challenges and various legal and regulatory risks. This chapter explores ways in which laws involving fraud and abuse, self-referral, private inurement, corporate practice of medicine, Medicare reimbursement policy, and antitrust enforcement affect typical integrated delivery systems. From a legal standpoint, it might seem logical that the laws regulating health care providers would support and promote integration. A permissive legal environment to foster development of an integrated service network model assumes its development in a delivery system in which networks are at financial risk for the services provided. However, many of the laws and regulations governing integrated provider development were established at a time when joint ventures and other alliances were organizing in a predominantly fee-for-service environment and were generating significant increases in health care costs without producing demonstrable efficiencies or quality enhancements. The result is a fundamental inconsistency in government policy. The demand for collaboration by purchasers and legislatures does not necessarily cause the vast body of health care regulators to revise their concerns that many of the very collaborative activities being encouraged trigger potentially illegal acts and relationships. In a market model, the application of federal and state antitrust laws is especially important. In 1993 and 1994, the Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission jointly issued "Statements of Antitrust Enforcement Policy" in a number of areas of provider uncertainty. For integrated delivery systems, the primary focus of antitrust analysis is "market power." Systems without market power (i.e., the ability to force a purchaser to do something that the purchaser would not do in a competitive market) cannot harm consumers and should be free form serious antitrust risk. Where a network may have market power, its activities may be limited only if demonstrable anticompetitive effects outweigh the benefits of the efficiencies claimed by the new arrangement. The chapter concludes that vigorous antitrust enforcement may be required to promote market competition among integrated networks of providers and the managed care plans they serve.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Strategic choices for a changing health care system, volume 2

TitleMain.Title: States and health care reform : the importance of program implementation

Abstract.AbstractText: The recent debate on national health care reform marked another case of policy being considered without reference to how--or even if--it could be implemented. The debate revolved around broad issues, such as universal versus partial coverage, mandatory versus voluntary alliances, and the respective roles of government and the market in health care. The ease or even the possibility of successful implementation was not an ingredient in evaluating proposals. The burden of making health care reform work falls to the states. Whether in response to national reform or in implementing their own programs, they must move from a general reform blueprint to an actual program that delivers services. The hands-on role of the states in designing and operating programs makes their implementation duties both unavoidable and critical. This chapter explores implementation issues that should be considered an integral part of planning for health care reform, at both the federal and the state level. The chapter has two goals. First, it makes a case for altering the usual approach to designing reform and recommends paying attention to implementation early in the policy process, rather than treating it as an afterthought. Second, it is intended to help policymakers design implementable programs and anticipate pitfalls. To achieve these goals, it examines the state role in health care reform; state capacity to carry out this role; examples of state health care reform initiatives and lessons for implementation drawn from these efforts; and barriers to successful implementation. The chapter concludes with recommendations for policymakers.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Strategic choices for a changing health care system, volume 2

TitleMain.Title: Redefining private insurance in a changing market structure

Abstract.AbstractText: This discussion on likely changes and challenges for the health insurance industry over the coming decade assumes that significant national reform of health care financing for the privately insured population will not occur--or, if it does, that it will mirror the insurance market reforms that many states already have undertaken. First, the changes in private insurance coverage during the past several years are considered, with particular attention to the erosion of employer-based coverage and to the rising influence of public insurance programs--especially Medicaid--on the private insurance market. Next is a description of the changing web of state laws and regulations governing private health insurance. At this writing, virtually every state has enacted or is considering reforms of the small group market to limit what many perceive as unfair or destructive insurer practices and to set new ground rules for competition among insurance arrangements. The changing nature of private insurance contracts in the United States is considered next. Evolving from conventional fee-for-service contracts, private insurance is increasingly a complex mixture of capitation, partial capitation, and reinsurance of capitated arrangements. Finally, this chapter discusses three issues of increasing importance in shaping the marketplace for private insurers: (1) the federal preemption of states' regulatory authority over self-insured employer plans; (2) emerging state regulation to restructure competition in the health insurance and health care markets; and (3) the growing interest of both federal and state governments in medical savings accounts to finance health insurance and health care spending.

TitleMain.Title: Developing the principles for internal data security of the EPR in the United Kingdom

Author.OtherInformation: Centre for Health Informatics, University of Wales, Aberystwyth, U.K.

Author.CollectiveName: International Symposium on the Creation of Electronic Health Record Systems

Abstract.AbstractText: This paper describes work undertaken over the past three years to explore the nature of internal data security in electronic patient records exchanged over wide area networks. The interactive relationships between a set of authoritative and generally accepted security principles, and an object-oriented model formalising them, are detailed. The testing of that model on a specialist case-tool by use of scenarios is also outlined. The aim of the paper is to stimulate exploration of the international facets of this work--the extent to which the findings in the United Kingdom are applicable throughout the industrial world.

TitleMain.Title: Violent or suicidal patients.

Abstract.AbstractText: Patients who are angry, frightened, disoriented, or mentally disturbed can often become violent toward themselves or others in the hospital. Much of the professional literature on violent or suicidal patients focuses on patients in psychiatric facilities (often admitted after an assault or suicide attempt), whose tendencies toward harming themselves or others is clearly recognized. Staff of psychiatric units in general hospitals are also trained to handle such patients. A significant number of violent events, however, occur in nonpsychiatric hospitals, and the literature reveals that in many instances, hospital staff were either unaware of the potential for such events, or unprepared to deal with them when they occurred. The need for staff to be trained to recognize and deal with potentially violent or suicidal patients, and to know how and when to seek assistance, should be of concern to the risk manager.

TitleMain.Title: Managed care for workers' compensation.

Abstract.AbstractText: Managed healthcare is a familiar concept in most hospitals. Hospital personnel communicate routinely with insurance company representatives and medical review organizations on behalf of patients. Group health insurance offered to hospital employees often includes managed-care components. Despite this familiarity, applying managed-care concepts and methods to Workers' Compensation is as new to the healthcare industry as it is to other industries. There are many reasons why managed-care concepts, widely applied in group health benefits, are only recently gaining acceptance in Workers' Compensation. These reasons, some historical and some legal, will be addressed in this article. Also discussed will be the potential pitfalls or obstacles that hospitals may encounter when incorporating managed-care concepts into their Workers' Compensation programs and how to avoid these obstacles and implement an effective program.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Healthcare Risk Control. Volume 2

TitleMain.Title: Data confidentiality and fourth-party auditing agencies.

Abstract.AbstractText: How should a hospital handle a request from fourth-party auditing agencies to inspect or copy a patient's medical record? This question is arising with increasing frequency as businesses and insurance companies seeking to reduce their healthcare costs hire outside agencies to perform utilization review (UR) of their employees' (or in the case of insurance companies, their consumers') health care services. Fourth-party auditing poses several risks for the hospital. Because it serves to further widen the circle of persons privy to medical record information, outside auditing increases the opportunities for improper disclosure of confidential information. This in turn increases the risk that the hospital, which is considered the custodian of such data, will be held liable. The hospital that grants such an agency access to medical records, without first taking several important cautionary measures, is potentially exposing itself to lawsuits brought by patients alleging breach of contract, defamation of character (if the information is inaccurate), or invasion of privacy. This article will briefly describe the measures that you, as risk manager, can take to reduce the risk to the hospital stemming from improper disclosure of confidential patient information.

TitleMain.Title: Home health services.

Abstract.AbstractText: Many risks are unique to the home care environment and are not encountered in the more controlled hospital setting. Clinical risks arise from limited control over patients' physical environment and their compliance with treatment plans, nurses and home health aides working alone with limited supervision, and increasingly complex and high-technology treatments being provided to sicker patients. Workers' Compensation risks stem from employees entering high-crime neighborhoods and the potential for employee automobile or other on-the-job accidents. This Self-Assessment Questionnaire (SAQ) helps risk managers evaluate their organization's program for these and other issues. We recommend that this SAQ be completed at least annually in conjunction with home care supervisors.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Healthcare Risk Control. Volume 1

TitleMain.Title: Bomb threats and "no-threat" bombs.

Abstract.AbstractText: A number of hospitals were called upon to respond to the bombing tragedy in Oklahoma City in April 1995. In addition to highlighting the need for overall disaster planning, this act of terrorism created another horror for these hospitals. While trying to treat the injured people, at least one hospital reported receiving several bomb threats. The hospital had to decide how to respond, including whether to evacuate the severely injured victims of the explosion. A difficult decision, under any circumstance, made even more difficult by confusion, stress, and fright. All hospitals should have an established contingency plan for dealing with bomb threats. The policy, typically part of an overall disaster plan, should define the responsibilities of all parties in the event of a bomb threat and outline immediate and follow-up procedures. The policy should also address the risk of "no-threat8 bombs--bombs that are exploded without warning. This self-assessment questionnaire identifies areas of concern for the hospital staff and administrators. Because these policies are likely to be used only infrequently and because turnover increases the chance that not all staff members are aware of these policies, this self-assessment should be performed twice a year and should include participation by the environmental manager, risk manager, the administrator, the director of safety and security, and all department managers.

Abstract.AbstractText: This Risk Analysis examines all facets of child abuse reporting by healthcare facilities and answers the following questions: (1) What is child abuse?; (2) Who is obligated to report suspicions of child abuse?; (3) How does one report suspected cases?; (4) Can liability follow a mistaken report?; (4) What are penalties for failure to report?; (5) What about patient confidentiality?

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Healthcare Risk Control. Volume 4

TitleMain.Title: COBRA's screening, stabilization, and transfer requirements.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Healthcare Risk Control. Volume 4

TitleMain.Title: Emergency department liability.

Abstract.AbstractText: Emergency department (ED) claims continue to rank high in frequency and severity, accounting for about 19% of the total number of claims and 18% of total dollars paid, according to one claims study. Various factors combine to expose EDs and the personnel who staff them to liability claims; chief among these is the sheer volume of patients who seek treatment at EDs each year. Courts have demonstrated their willingness to hold hospitals liable for the negligence of emergency physicians, despite their status as independent contractors. Certain conditions and events related to the practice of emergency medicine tend to reappear in one malpractice claim after another. Delays and diagnostic errors are common allegations in ED malpractice claims. Consent, confidentiality, and interdepartmental communications are also major areas of risk management concern. Other "red flags" that may indicate potential liability exposures are moonlighting, inadequate resident supervision, shift work, shift changes, patients leaving against medical advice, return visits, admitting orders, telephone orders, multiple-system injuries, language barriers, discharge instructions, and documentation. Risk managers should develop strategies to reduce these areas of exposure and should identify other potential trouble spots.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Healthcare Risk Control. Volume 4

TitleMain.Title: Medical device tracking.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Healthcare Risk Control. Volume 2

TitleMain.Title: Contractual liability.

Abstract.AbstractText: Hospitals enter into myriad contracts; medical staffing agreements, educational affiliation agreements, purchase orders, maintenance contracts, building and equipment leases, and construction contracts are but a few. In many cases these contracts are negotiated and signed by a department manager with no review by administration, risk management, or in-house counsel. Yet, each contract has risk management implications because each may expose the hospital to unanticipated economic loss. As with the review of malpractice claims and settlements, contract review is a risk management identification process. It enables the risk manager to monitor potential exposures and to consider transferring the risk of loss. Certain contracts will always require review by outside counsel, even if the risk manager is an attorney. But with many other contracts, the risk manager can perform a knowledgeable and careful review. Other articles in Healthcare Risk Control discuss specific types of contracts (e.g., managed-care contracts, hospital-physician contracts, equipment service contracts). This Risk Analysis provides a general overview of the essential elements of a risk management contract review program.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Healthcare Risk Control. Volume 2

TitleMain.Title: Corporate liability.

Abstract.AbstractText: A series of court cases decided over the past 20 years has caused a metamorphosis in hospital liability for physician negligence. These cases have firmly established the concept of hospital corporate liability--liability that attaches directly to the hospital--as an entity. Under the doctrine of corporate liability, the hospital owes an independent legal duty to its patients or other third parties to monitor the quality of medical care provided by its independent staff physicians. This duty is nondelegable and is separate and distinct from the physician's individual duty of care. In addition, there are several corporate duties that courts have traditionally applied to hospitals, as well as other businesses, such as the duty to properly select and maintain equipment, select and retain personnel, and maintain the premises. This Risk Analysis will discuss the expansion of hospital liability and will review the corporate duties of hospitals under current law.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Healthcare Risk Control. Volume 2

TitleMain.Title: Informed consent.

Abstract.AbstractText: Informed consent continues to be a liability exposure for healthcare practitioners and institutions. The duty of healthcare professionals to provide comprehensive information to patients regarding the risks, benefits, side effects, and alternatives to medical procedures is firmly established by both common and statutory law; however, confusion still remains over what constitutes proper disclosure to patients, when this information must be disclosed, and which of the many healthcare providers participating in a patient's care has the duty of disclosure. This Risk Analysis discusses the current approaches to each of these questions and suggests ways to minimize consent liability for your facility and medical staff.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Healthcare Risk Control. Volume 3

TitleMain.Title: Preventing resident abuse and neglect.

Abstract.AbstractText: Risk managers must be sensitive to the potential for not only civil liability, but also criminal liability, for individuals who abuse or neglect residents and for nursing facilities, administrators, directors of nursing, and medical directors who fail in their duty to safeguard the welfare of residents in the facility. Loss of Medicare and Medicaid funding can also result. This Risk Analysis helps risk managers: (1) Understand the underlying causes of resident abuse; (2) Familiarize themselves with laws, standards, and guidelines on resident abuse; (3) Develop abuse-prevention strategies; (4) Know what to do if abuse occurs in their facility; (5) Access additional information on resident abuse.

OtherSubject.OtherSubjectName: Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Healthcare Risk Control. Volume 3

TitleMain.Title: Termination of life-sustaining treatment.

Abstract.AbstractText: This Risk Analysis highlights the major issues relating to terminating life-sustaining treatment for the risk manager and provides guidance in developing institutional policies and procedures. State statutes, judicial decisions, professional guidelines, accreditation standards, and federal Medicare regulation are all addressed. Guidelines from the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organization (JCAHO) and numerous hospitals are also included. The article is divided into several sections presenting different scenarios that may be encountered when dealing with the termination of life-sustaining treatment. Each section addresses a key factor in the decision-making process: (1) whether the patient has or lacks decision-making capacity; (2) whether the patient is terminally ill (expected to die within days or weeks even if all treatment is continued, or alternatively, can be expected to live for a long period of time if life-sustaining treatment is provided; and (3) whether the patient has executed an advance directive (or, without a formal document, how well known the patient's wishes and beliefs are about life-sustaining treatment). The article recommends that risk managers develop and implement hospitalwide policies and procedures on forgoing or withdrawing life-sustaining treatments in accordance with JCAHO standards and state laws. These policies and procedures should: include a process for determining a patient's decision-making capacity; seek to minimize the need for court involvement; ascertain the existence of a patient's advance directives upon admission to the institution; and foster increased respect for patient's rights. It is also advised that risk managers ensure that pertinent medical, nursing, and administrative staffs are educated on state law regarding termination of life-sustaining treatment.

TitleMain.Title: Human rights are women's right.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: New York, New York, Amnesty International, 1995.
PublicationInfo.Place: New York, New York, Amnesty International,

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: The introduction to this report and commentary by Amnesty International (AI) defines women's rights as universal and indivisible, sets forth the challenges that face human rights activists, defines the manifestations of violence against women, identifies this report as one of AI's contributions to the worldwide campaign for women's human rights, and outlines the way forward. The first chapter considers the effects on women of war, including rape, dislocation, and widowhood. Chapter 2 describes the work of women activists in trade unions, politics, human rights efforts, local communities, crusades for justice, the law, and anti-war efforts. The third chapter reports on situations in which women have been placed at risk while in custody, by laws, or by society or have been persecuted unfairly. Chapter 4 offers the following steps that can be taken to protect women's human rights: 1) recognize that women's human rights are universal and indivisible; 2) ratify and implement international human rights treaties; 3) eradicate discrimination; 4) safeguard women's human rights during armed conflict; 5) eliminate rape, sexual abuse, and torture/ill-treatment by government agents and paramilitary forces; 6) prevent "disappearances" and extrajudicial executions by government agents and compensate victims; 7) stop persecution based on family connections; 8) safeguard the health rights of women in custody; 9) release all prisoners of conscience immediately and unconditionally; 10) ensure prompt and fair trials for all political prisoners; 11) prevent human rights violations against women refugees and asylum-seekers and displaced women; 12) abolish the death penalty; 13) support the work of relevant intergovernmental and nongovernmental organizations; 14) promote women's rights as human rights through official programs of education and training; and 15) compel armed political groups to safeguard women's human rights. The appendix contains a commentary about female genital mutilation and reproduces UN documents on the elimination of violence and discrimination directed towards women.

TitleMain.Title: The Human Rights Watch global report on women's human rights.

Author.CollectiveName: Human Rights Watch. Women's Rights Project.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: New York, New York, Human Rights Watch, 1995.
PublicationInfo.Place: New York, New York, Human Rights Watch,

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: This book describes incidences of women's human rights violations complied by Human Rights Watch from 1990-95. The introduction reviews the range and severity of abuse, the climate of silence and impunity surrounding human rights violations, the challenge ahead, and recommended actions. Individual chapters open with a general discussion of the topic and end by presenting specific recommendations to the responsible government and the international community of actions to end the impunity and prevent future abuses. The first chapter concentrates on the use of rape as a weapon of war and a tool of political repression and presents case studies of rape and murder of civilian women in Bosnia-Herzegovina, Somalia, Haiti, India, and Peru. Chapter 2, covering the sexual assault of refugee and displaced women, describes the plights of Burmese refugees in Bangladesh and Somali refugees in Kenya. The third chapter deals with abuses against women in custody using examples from Pakistan, the US, and Egypt. Chapter 4 discusses the trafficking of women and girls into forced prostitution and coerced marriage and highlights the plight of Burmese females sent to Thailand, Nepali females trafficked to India, and Bangladeshi females taken to Pakistan. Chapter 5 reviews abuses against women workers through a look at Asian domestic workers in Kuwait and discrimination against woman workers in Russia and in post-Communist Poland. The sixth chapter examines domestic violence by considering violence against women in Brazil, Russia, and South Africa. The final chapter is concerned with human rights violations in the areas of reproduction and sexuality. Examples include forced virginity examinations in Turkey, the abortion debate and civil rights violations in Ireland, and abortion restrictions in post-Communist Poland.

TitleMain.Title: Annual report, 1994 : A CLO report on the state of human rights in Nigeria.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: This annual report details the human and civil rights abuses perpetrated in Nigeria in 1994. The first chapter lists such police abuses as extrajudicial murders and extortion and provides a report on a Civil Liberties Organisation/Police workshop that sought to make the police understand that they must respect human rights. Chapter 2 describes prison conditions including the inadequate diet of prisoners, the strike by the wardens, imprisonment of innocent people, prison deaths, the results of a prison tour, and the results of appeals launched on behalf of specific prisoners. The third chapter covers the state of freedom of the press and freedom of expression and includes accounts of confiscation of materials, harassment of journalists, and censorship. Chapter 4 reviews academic freedom and the right to an education, which was compromised by the institution of school fees. Results of a campus-to-campus human rights watch are reported for 26 institutions of higher learning. Chapter 5 discusses the military, the political transition program, and civil liberties abuses, specifically the arrest of Chief M. K. O. Abiola whose election to the presidency of the country in 1993 was annulled. The next chapter sets forth abuses perpetrated by the prevailing Abacha regime as it implemented arbitrary arrests and detention, used the courts to further its purpose, and charged senators who sought to reconvene the senate of the National Assembly with treason. Chapter 7 covers the deterioration of economic and social rights that led to strikes by essential workers, increases in oil prices, inflation, and deteriorating health care services. The eighth and final chapter relates abuses of minority rights (including genocide) and examples of severe environmental degradation.

TitleMain.Title: A woman's legal right to choose

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Women's rights to choose abortion are governed by local legal systems which fall into one of the following classes: comprehensively codified laws, in which any right must have its basis in a code provision; judicially developed systems, in which judges declare customary or common law; and religious law, revealed to and declared by religious authorities. These various legal systems are discussed followed by consideration of the following types of law: constitutional law; criminal, noncriminal, and administrative law; legislation; judicial decisions; and international human rights law. Specific abortion laws are discussed. The transition to health-based law, medical advances, and legal respect for human rights are covered in the closing section on future legal challenges.

TitleMain.Title: Primer Encuentro de Investigadores sobre Aborto Inducido en América Latina y el Caribe : conclusiones y recomendaciones
TitleMain.OtherInformation: / compilación, Lucero Zamudio, Norma Rubiano ; transcripción y primera revisión, Ana María Pizarro.

TitleOther.TitleAlternate: First Meeting of Investigators on Induced Abortion in Latin America and the Caribbean. Conclusions and recommendations.

Author.CollectiveName: Encuentro de Investigadores sobre Aborto Inducido en América Latina y el Caribe

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Santafé de Bogotá, D.C. : [Universidad Externado de Colombia, 1995]

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: The First Meeting of Investigators on Induced Abortion in Latin America and the Caribbean, held in Bogota in November 1994, was attended by 135 researchers, legislators, and institutional observers from 22 nations. 60 works were presented in seven sessions covering abortion incidence; abortion determinants and associated factors; abortion services and practice; hospital care and costs of abortion; the impact of abortion; social concepts and social movements; and methodologic aspects. A summary of abortion law in the region and presentations on ethicoreligious aspects and on the effects of legalization on administration of abortion services were also included. At the close of the meeting, the participants divided into five working groups to prepare conclusions and recommendations concerning incidence and legislation; adolescence, undesired pregnancy, and abortion; hospital care and abortion costs; contraception and abortion; and maternal mortality and abortion. In addition to the recommendations formulated by the five working groups, recommendations were made for a research agenda and for a political agenda, and the attending legislators outlined a series of recommendations addressed to the Latin American Parliament. The conclusions and recommendations of the different groups are described in this document.

TitleMain.Title: Three strikes and you're out : the demography of mandatory prison sentencing
TitleMain.OtherInformation: / C.P. Schmertmann, A.A. Amankwaa, R.D. Long.

Abstract.AbstractText: Many state governments are currently considering versions of "Three Strikes and You're Out" (3SYO) laws that would mandate life sentences in prison for three-time felons. In this paper the authors investigate the demographic effects of mandatory sentencing policies on the size and age structure of state prison populations, with special emphasis on 3SYO. Their goal is to improve the quality of information available to policy makers about the demographic consequences of mandatory sentencing. They illustrate the consequences of 3SYO using a multistate projection model of age-specific prison entries and exits. Rates in the model are based on unusually detailed data from the Florida Department of Corrections. The authors estimate that a 3SYO policy would nearly double the number of prisoners in a state such as Florida, and they find that in the long run 3SYO would change the age structure of the prison population very substantially.

TitleMain.Title: The reuse of medical devices supplied for single use only.

Abstract.AbstractText: The practice of reusing medical devices labelled by the manufacturer for single use only must be carefully considered by managers and others with responsibility for patient safety, to ensure that full account has been taken of outcomes which may be harmful to the patient and may affect a clinical procedure adversely. There are a number of potential hazards associated with reprocessing and reusing medical devices intended for single use. Such reprocessed devices should not be used on patients, therefore, unless the reprocessing method has been validated to prove its safety and efficacy and that the finished product is suitable for its intended purpose. Users who disregard this information and prepare single use products for further use, without due precautions, may be transferring legal liability for the safe performance of the product from the manufacturer to themselves, or to the organization that employs them. It should be noted that if a reprocessed device is placed on the market, it must comply with the statutory requirements described in the Medical Devices Regulations 1994.

TitleMain.Title: Digital management and regulatory submission of medical images from clinical trials : role and benefits of the core laboratory
TitleMain.OtherInformation: / W. L. Robbins, J. J. Conklin.

Author.OtherInformation: Bio-Imaging Technologies, Inc., West Trenton, New Jersey 08628, USA.

Author.CollectiveName: Health Care Technology Policy II: The Role of Technology in the Cost of Health Care: Providing the Solution

Abstract.AbstractText: Medical images (Angiography, CT, MRI, Nuclear Medicine, Ultrasound, X-ray) play an increasingly important role in the clinical development and regulatory review process for pharmaceuticals and medical devices. Since medical images are increasingly acquired and archived digitally, or are readily digitized from film, they can be visualized, processed and analyzed in a variety of ways using digital image processing and display technology. Moreover, with image-based data management and data visualization tools, medical images can be electronically organized and submitted to the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (F.D.A.) for review. The collection, processing, analysis, archival and submission of medical images in a digital format versus an analog (film-based) format presents both challenges and opportunities for the clinical and regulatory information management specialist. The medical imaging "core laboratory" is an important resource for clinical trials and regulatory submissions involving medical imaging data. Use of digital imaging technology within a core laboratory can increase efficiency and decrease overall costs in the image data management and regulatory review process.

TitleMain.Title: Telemedicine : legal and licensure issues
TitleMain.OtherInformation: / M. B. Wood, L. J. Whelan.

Author.CollectiveName: Health Care Technology Policy II: The Role of Technology in the Cost of Health Care: Providing the Solution

Abstract.AbstractText: The National Information Infrastructure program offers a great opportunity for the United States to capitalize on remarkable technological advancements over a broad range of applications benefiting society. One such application, telemedicine, has the potential to offer widespread access to sophisticated medical care, curtailed health care delivery costs and homogeneous health and health-related educational opportunities. However, there are a variety of barriers to widespread application of telemedicine once the technical infrastructure of the information highway is well established and ubiquitous. These barriers include technical limitations, reimbursement issues, equipment and networking costs and appropriate scientific studies to document efficacy and cost effectiveness. These issues may prove to be only transient disincentives which can be surmounted. Additional barriers exist, however, that may not be as readily resolved by traditional methods of analysis and more widespread practice applications. These political and regulatory obstacles will require clarification of the issues and solutions based on national consensus. It is the purpose of this discussion to amplify on these particular barriers which include licensure and tort jurisdiction.

TitleMain.Title: Drugs and crime : evaluating public policy initiatives
TitleMain.OtherInformation: / edited by Doris Layton MacKenzie, Craig D. Uchida.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: (Publisher-supplied data) "Choose Drugs and Crime when you want a critical overview of public policy issues on law enforcement and regulation: It focuses on major policy initiatives and the implications of research conducted on their effectiveness. The evaluations of policy results are practical and focus on verifiable results." --The Midwest Book Review Addressing critical areas of drug control and system improvement, Drugs and Crime provides a clear and comprehensive examination of policy relevant research. Editors, MacKenzie and Uchida enlist outstanding experts in the field to produce a volume that explores the major problems related to drug trafficking and use. Each chapter focuses on a major policy initiative and discusses the problem area, policies designed to address the problem, research on the effectiveness of the policies, and policy implications of the research. Just how effective is the criminal justice system in its response to drug use by children and adolescents, prison overcrowding, backlog in the courts, increased criminal activity, youths in the drug distribution system, and serious illnesses such as AIDS? Policymakers, scholars, practitioners, and students will find the "what we know" and "what we need to know" presentations in Drugs and Crime a most unique and appealing addition to the literature and a valuable resource in the continuing effort to understand the complex relationship between drug use and crime.
